head.supplied: 17/9/94 ¶ ¶ Your Mosses arrived this morning, dear Mr Musson, ¶ and shall be attended to. Whenever the naming is done I will send a list. If I can aid your studies in any way, it shall be done with ...

div.p: ML MSS.2009/21, item 27, Linnean Society of NSW, Mitchell Library, State Library of New South Wales, Sydney.

proofed.
MS is accompanied by an envelope. The front is marked: ' On Her Majesty's Sevice
. | Ch T. Musson Esq | FLS., Lecturer at the | Hawkesb. Agric. | College, Richmond, | near | Sydney. | Government Botanist , Melbourne, 17/9/1894.' The front also bears the stamp and crest of the Chief Secretary of Victoria and is date stamped Melbourne, 18 September 1894. The back is date stamped Richmond and Sydney both on 19 September 1894. 17/9/94

Your Mosses arrived this morning, dear Mr Musson,
See also M to C. Musson, 4 September 1894. and shall be attended to. Whenever the naming is done I will send a list. If I can aid your studies in any way, it shall be done with pleasure.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: Should you happen to have surplus specimens of any very rare NSW. plants available, or within reach I could utilize them under your name for my foreign inter changes.

Would you be able to ascertain, whether the Atkinsonia like the Nuytsia makes offshoots from its roots, by which means new plants are produced? If you happen to be in the locality of growth, you might kindly also be able to ascertain, whether Atkinsonia simply grows in debris of various plants, or roots on a host under ground. You likely will be out anyhow in the course of the spring in the Atkinsonia locality. I should like to have also a cross section of the wood.
Have you carefully collected all the floating and sub merged plants of your River? and lagoons & you might find perhaps Aldrovanda
